intro: Silene menziesii subsp. williamsii, commonly known as the Williams' catchfly, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the Caryophyllaceae family and is characterized by its slender stems and clusters of small, pinkish-white flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils, often in arid or semi-arid environments. It produces small, capsule-like fruits that contain numerous seeds, which are dispersed by wind. This subspecies is adapted to withstand drought conditions, making it a resilient component of its native ecosystem.
